questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of bright red blood in his stool for 5 days. He has had no pain during defecation and no abdominal pain. One year ago, he was diagnosed with liver cirrhosis after being admitted to the emergency department for upper gastrointestinal bleeding. He has since reduced his drinking and consumes around 2 bottles of beer daily. Examination shows scleral icterus and mild ankle swelling. Palpation of the abdomen shows a fluid thrill. Anoscopy shows enlarged bluish vessels above the dentate line. Which of the following is this patient's most likely source of bleeding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superior Rectal vein The patient's findings of anorectal varices and past medical history of cirrhosis and upper GI bleeding suggest portal hypertension. Anorectal varices occur in patients with portal hypertension due to increased blood flow in the portosystemic anastomoses that connect the superior rectal vein with the inferior and middle rectal veins. The superior rectal vein receives blood from the region of the anal canal above the dentate line and drains into the inferior mesenteric vein (portal venous circulation). The superior rectal vein would be the source of bleeding in the case of lesions located above the dentate line , such as the anorectal varices seen in this patient. The inferior rectal veins, which receive blood from the region below the dentate line and drain into the internal pudendal veins (systemic venous circulation), would be the source of bleeding in the case of lesions below the dentate line, such as external hemorrhoids.

Highyeild:

Four degrees of haemorrhoids First degree – bleed only, no prolapse Second-degree – prolapse but reduced spontaneously Third degree – prolapse but have to be manually reduced Fourth degree – permanently prolapsed

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option B - Blood from the region of the anal canal below the pectinate line drains into the internal pudendal veins via its tributary. The anorectal varices in this patient are located above the dentate line, so a different vessel is the more likely source of bleeding. External hemorrhoids manifest with a painful rectal bleeding drain into the internal pudendal veins. Option C- The inferior mesenteric artery does supply blood to the region of the anal canal above the dentate line via its branch, the superior rectal artery. However, this patient's bleeding source is an enlarged tortuous vein (varix), not an artery. Option. D- The inferior rectal veins receive blood from the region of the anal canal below the dentate line . The anorectal varices in this patient are located above the dentate line, so a different vessel is the more likely source of bleeding. The inferior rectal veins are the source of bleeding in external hemorrhoids, manifesting in painful rectal bleeding.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of painless bleeding during defecation for 3 days. She has defecated once per day. Her father died of colon cancer 4 years ago. Her only medication is an iron supplement. On examination, a pinkish mass appears at the anal orifice when the patient is asked to exhale against closed nostrils but spontaneously reduces when breathing normally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

lifestyle modification + banding Conservative therapy is the first-line management of external, grade I, and grade II internal hemorrhoids. GRADING AND MANAGEMENT OF HEMORRHOIDS : GRADE SYMPTOMS AND SIGNS MANAGEMENT 1 BLEEDING NO PROLAPSE LIFESTYLE CHANGES LAXATIVE SITZ BATH 2 PROLAPSE WITH SPONTANEOUS REDUCTION LIFESTYLE CHANGES + BANDING >> SCLEROTHERAPY 3 PROLAPSE REQUIRING MANUAL REDUCTION II + SURGERY 4 PROLAPSE CAN NOT BE REDUCED SURGERY

Highyeild:

Internal hemorrhoids are found above the dentate line and are typically painless. They can be treated by ligation and banding , the preferred method. External hemorrhoids , on the other hand, are located below the dentate line and can be painful. They are also known as five-day self-curing lesions. Treatment typically involves excision , as ligation is not recommended. Repeated thrombosis can cause the hemorrhoids to take on a semi-ripe black currant appearance. Treatment of haemorrhoids Symptomatic – advice about defecatory habits, stool softeners and bulking agents Injection of sclerosant Rubber banding HAL/stapled haemorrhoidopexy Haemorrhoidectomy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option. A - Injection sclerotherapy is first-line therapy for grade III internal hemorrhoids, but it is usually used for grade I and grade II internal hemorrhoids that persist despite conservative therapy. Grade III internal hemorrhoids originate above the dentate line, prolapse when straining, and require manual reduction (i.e., do not reduce spontaneously). Because this patient has grade II internal hemorrhoids, a more conservative approach must first be considered. Option. B - Surgery is considered in Grade III and GRADE IV Hemorrhoids . Option. D - Topical diltiazem may relieve the spasm of the anal sphincter in patients with painful thrombosed external hemorrhoids or following hemorrhoidectomy. It is also used as first-line management for chronic anal fissures . Patients with chronic anal fissures may present with rectal bleeding and an anal skin tag, as seen in this patient. Although anal fissures may coexist with prolapsed hemorrhoids, they are always associated with pain during and after defecation. In addition, patients usually present with symptoms lasting more than 8–12 weeks.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of several episodes of per rectal bleeding for 2 weeks. He has had pain around the anal area for the past month. Six months ago, he was diagnosed with oesophagal candidiasis and was treated with oral fluconazole. He is HIV-positive. He has had 9 male sexual partners over his lifetime and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Digital rectal examination and anoscopy show a hard 2-cm mass palpable 0.5 cm above the anal verge that bleeds on contact. There is no inguinal lymphadenopathy. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. The CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 95/mm3. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis. This patient is most likely to benefit from which of the following interventions?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Radiochemotherapy The patient has anal carcinoma . The incidence of anal cancer is higher in individuals infected with HIV and in men who have sex with men (MSM), as in this patient. The other risk factors for Anal carcinoma are 1.HPV{Human Papilloma virus }2. Immunocompromised state 3. Post-transplant status. Anal cancer typically presents as an exophytic, hard anal mass often tender and bleeds easily. The treatment of choice is NIGRO’S REGIME - The combination of chemotherapy and radiation is the treatment of choice for patients with anal squamous cell cancer ; it is superior to surgery, with a 5-year survival rate of ∼ 80%. Subsequent surgery{APR} is only indicated if a residual tumour is confirmed with biopsy after the completion of radiochemotherapy and recurrence after chemoradiotherapy(20%-30%).

Highyeild:

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is the most common type of cancer in the anal canal, followed by basal cell carcinoma (BCC) and melanoma . The median age at diagnosis is typically around 60 years old. The most common symptom of anal canal cancer is rectal bleeding . When anal canal cancer metastasises, the most common site for metastasis is the lungs . In terms of lymph node metastasis, the inguinal lymph nodes are the most commonly affected. Squamous cell carcinoma of anal rim

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option. B - Abdominoperineal resection (APR) is indicated in certain patients with low-lying rectal adenocarcinomas that cannot be treated with sphincter-sparing procedures and those with adenocarcinomas of the anal canal. However, adenocarcinomas of the anal canal are rare and not the most likely diagnosis in a young patient without a family history of colorectal cancer or other predisposing factors like inflammatory bowel disease, smoking, or alcohol consumption. Option. C - Local cytostatic treatment with 5-fluorouracil is indicated in patients with anogenital warts (i.e., condylomata acuminata ). Although anogenital warts may manifest as painful lesions, like those seen in this patient, they usually present as cauliflower-like lumps, not a hard mass, and rectal bleeding is a rare sequelae. Option. D - Total mesorectal excision is usually performed with low anterior resection in patients with rectal adenocarcinoma . However, the patient's tumor is just above the anal verge, within the anal canal, rather than the rectum. In addition, adenocarcinoma is unlikely in a young patient without predisposing factors such as a family history of colorectal cancer, inflammatory bowel disease, smoking, or alcohol consumption.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of pain during defecation for 2 weeks, lasting several hours. She reports that she often strains during defecation and sees bright red blood on toilet paper after wiping. She typically has 3 bowel movements per week. Physical examination shows a longitudinal, perianal tear. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by tissue injury in which of the following locations?

options.label: A
options.text: Posterior midline of anal canal distal to the pectinate line due to ischemia and anterior midline distal to the pectinate line following vaginal delivery

options.label: B
options.text: The anterior midline of the anal canal proximal to the pectinate line due to ischemia

options.label: C
options.text: Posterior midline of the anal canal proximal to the pectinate line due to vaginal delivery

options.label: D
options.text: Anterior midline of anal canal distal to the pectinate line due to ischemia

questions.correct_answer: A. Posterior midline of anal canal distal to the pectinate line due to ischemia and anterior midline distal to the pectinate line following vaginal delivery
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Posterior midline of anal canal distal to the pectinate line due to ischemia and anterior midline distal to the pectinate line following vaginal delivery Approximately 90% of anal fissures occur at the posterior midline of the anal canal, distal to the pectinate line (dentate line)and anterior midline to the pectinate line following vaginal delivery. The etiology is usually benign and primary, with the most common cause being local trauma (e.g., passing of hard stools due to constipation), persistent diarrhoea, vaginal delivery, or anal sex. This predilection for the posterior midline is likely due to poor perfusion in this area. A skin tag (sentinel pile) formed by hypertrophied papillae would often be visible in the perianal region at the fissure site.

Highyeild:

Treatment of an anal fissure Conservative initially, consisting of stool-bulking agents and softeners, and chemical agents in the form of ointments that are designed to relax the anal sphincter and improve blood flow Surgery if above fails, consisting of lateral internal sphincterotomy or anal advancement flap Anal fissure

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option. B- The region of the anal canal proximal to the pectinate line is a common location for internal hemorrhoids and adenocarcinoma of the anal canal . In contrast, anal fissures occur distal to the pectinate line. Internal hemorrhoids are characterised by the passage of bright red blood per rectum with a bowel movement. However, defecation is usually painless. Option. C- The region of the anal canal proximal to the pectinate line is a common location for internal hemorrhoids , whereas anal fissures occur distal to the pectinate line. Internal hemorrhoids are characterised by the passage of bright red blood per rectum with a bowel movement. However, defecation is usually painless. Option. D- Anal fissures occur at the anterior midline of the anal canal , distal to the pectinate line following vaginal delivery and not ischemia. Anal fissures at this location are usually secondary to anal surgery , IBD (e.g., Crohn's disease ), infections (e.g., syphilis ) or malignancy ( leukemia ). There is no evidence of an underlying condition in this patient that would make an anal fissure at an atypical location likely.

Extraedge:

Acute anal fissures are characterised by severe pain during bowel movements and the passage of fresh blood, which can be noticed on tissue after wiping. A hypertrophied anal papilla, sentinel tag, and deep canoe-shaped ulcer characterise chronic anal fissures .

Sitz bath and topical nifedipine Sitz baths and topical nifedipine are recommended as the initial therapy for most anal fissures . A sitz bath may reduce sphincter tone and promote blood flow to the anal mucosa. At the same time, nifedipine promotes mucosal healing by increasing blood flow to the anal mucosa and reducing the sphincter tone.

questions.text: A 30-year-old driver was diagnosed with pilonidal sinus. Which of the following statement is false regarding the disease?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a disease of the elderly

options.label: D
options.text: It has been referred to as jeep driver's disease/bottom.

questions.correct_answer: A. It is a disease of the elderly
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is a disease of the elderly Almost exclusively young men are affected by this condition. More than 80% of sufferers are men in their third decade . They have hairy buttocks where friction causes the hair shed to burrow through the midline skin, forming a track and an abscess. Therefore recurrent abscesses are common, requiring incision and drainage with curettage of the granulation tissue and hair. Definitive Surgery is Rhomboid / Limberg flap Other procedures are Kardyakis Surgery and Bascom Procedure .

Highyeild:

Pilonidal Sinus It is an acquired disease commonly seen in hairy males aged 20-29 years . It is found in the natal cleft overlying the coccyx. It consists of non-infected midline openings that communicate with a fibrous track lined by granulation tissue and containing loose hair. It is common among military personnel and is also known as jeep disease . Hair follicles have not been found in the walls of the sinus. The hairs projecting from the sinus are dead and pointed towards the blind end of the sinus. Recurrence is common even after adequate excision of the track is carried out.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anal fissure occurs most commonly at 9 o’clock position The most common site of an anal fissure is the posterior midline at the 6 o’clock position , probably because of the excessive shearing force acting at that part during defecation. The usual cause is trauma caused by the passage of a constipated hard stool. Anterior fissure is more commonly seen in women, probably due to vaginal delivery. When a fissure occurs at a site away from the usual point in the anus, almost always there is an underlying cause, such as Crohn’s disease, tuberculosis, HIV-related ulcers, or squamous cell carcinoma . In such a situation, the patient should be examined under anaesthesia, and relevant biopsies should be taken.

Pilonidal sinus disease is an acquired condition. It is typically seen in hairy males. The disease is most commonly found in the natal cleft overlying the coccyx. It is usually diagnosed in the age group of 20-29 years. The etiopathogenesis of the disease is not well-understood. Hair follicles have rarely been demonstrated in the walls of the sinus. Hair projecting from the sinus are typically dead and has pointed ends directed towards the blind end of the sinus. Recurrence of the disease is common, even after adequate excision of the track.

Extraedge:

Pilonidal sinus disease is more commonly seen in dark-haired individuals. Patients typically experience intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine. A history of repeated abscesses that have burst spontaneously or have been incised away from the midline is often present. The primary sinus may have one or multiple openings, all of which are strictly in the midline between the level of the sacrococcygeal joint and the tip of the coccyx. Interdigital pilonidal sinus is an occupational disease of hairdressers. The disease can also occur in the axilla and umbilicus.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complains of bright-red painless per rectal bleeding for 6 weeks. This is not mixed with her stools and comes on whenever she opens her bowels. It started toward the end of her pregnancy and got worse after the birth of her baby 2 months ago. She has no other symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hemorrhoids This young woman’s history suggests piles resulting from pregnancy. After a history, she is examined by proctosigmoidoscopy to confirm the piles' degree. The history is suggestive of first-degree piles. At the outset, she is advised conservative management – normalising bowel habits, stool-softening agents and minimising straining.

Highyeild:

According to modern theories, hemorrhoids are considered normal anatomical structures. These structures consist of cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, smooth muscle fibres, and elastic connective tissue, also known as VASE. The anal canal has three hemorrhoidal cushions in the left lateral, right anterior, and right posterior positions at 3, 7, and 11 o'clock, respectively. Hemorrhoids, also known as piles, are anal cushions that can become symptomatic, causing discomfort and pain Hemorrhoids are more likely to occur when there is an increase in intra-abdominal pressure, which can be caused by factors such as obesity, constipation, and pregnancy. Typical symptoms of hemorrhoids include bright-red, painless bleeding, mucus discharge, and prolapse. Although it's difficult to palpate hemorrhoids, they can be diagnosed more accurately through proctoscopy.

The mere presence of hemorrhoids does not necessarily require treatment; only symptomatic hemorrhoids should be treated. Treatment for hemorrhoids should be as minimally invasive as possible while effectively alleviating symptoms.

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman k/c/o COPD complains of a large lump protruding from her back for a few years. This is associated with mucus discharge and faecal incontinence. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rectal prolapse The patient has Rectal prolapse . Full-thickness rectal prolapse (complete prolapse) is six times more common in women. The complications are bleeding , incarceration and small-bowel evisceration . The management consist of a colonoscopy or a flexible sigmoidoscopy to exclude any mucosal lesions. Surgery is the mainstay of treatment, the options being abdominal or perineal approach, the former being open or laparoscopic.

Highyeild:

Rectal prolapse is a medical condition where the rectum protrudes through the anus approximately 1-4cm. The condition may present in two forms, mucosal or full thickness. In the latter, the whole rectal wall is involved. The condition may start as an internal rectal prolapse or rectal intussusception. In children, the prolapse is commonly mucosal and can be treated non-invasively. However, in adults, the prolapse is often full-thickness and associated with symptoms of constipation and incontinence. A. Full-thickness rectal prolapse and B. Mucosal prolapse

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A : Villous adenomas are usually very large with a typical frond-like appearance often occupying the entire rectum. These might present with profuse watery, mucoid diarrhoea, making the patient very weak because of the loss of large amounts of potassium. They have a propensity to malignant change, something that can be strongly suspected on digital examination. Option B: Patients with rectal carcinoma typically complain of ‘early-morning spurious diarrhoea’.The patient typically complains of having to wake up in the morning earlier than usual because of an intense desire to defecate only to rush to the lavatory to pass ‘wind and water’, which the patient refers to as ‘diarrhoea’; this is ‘spurious’ because it is false as there are no faeces but just pent-up mucus secretion proximal to an obstruction. The patient has to make several such trips, being left with a constant desire to defecate – a symptom called tenesmus . Option D : Solitary rectal ulcer Also called solitary rectal ulcer syndrome (SRUS),is often associated with other pelvic floor disorders. Despite the name, sometimes there might be no ulcer, while there might be multiple ulcers or erosions. Typically there is an ulcer in the anterior rectal wall when a carcinoma or inflammatory bowel disease must be excluded. It might heal by itself, leaving a polypoid-looking lesion. Management of SRUS is STARR procedure{Stapled Transanal Rectal Resection of Intussusception}

Extraedge:

Surgery is usually required to correct full-thickness rectal prolapse. The procedure may be performed through the perineum or the abdomen.
